Article.Abstract: Cytotoxic T-lymphocyte (CTL) response is an important component of anti-viral immunity. CTLs are specific to short peptides presented by MHC-I molecules and immunisation with the exact peptide sequence introduced in the cytosol is therefore a minimal approach, which potentially affords a high degree of controllability. We have examined the induction of murine CTL's by this approach using DNA plasmid minigene vaccines encoding known mouse K(k) minimal CTL epitopes (8 amino acids) from the influenza A virus hemagglutinin and nucleoprotein. We here report that such an approach is feasible and that wild type influenza virus flanking amino acid sequences can influence the CTL response but are not essential for optimal CTL induction. We also examined the effect of different new amino acid sequences flanking the CTL epitopes. In one version, two CTL epitopes were linked together as 'string of beads'. This did not improve CTL induction. In another version, one CTL epitope was inserted into a known T-helper protein (HBsAg). This did significantly augment the response probably due to immunological help from HBsAg Th epitopes. Finally, the CTL inducing minigene DNA vaccines were compared with Flu-induced CTL responses and tested for their protective effect against a lethal influenza A virus infection in mice and no effect was found. We conclude that a specific and highly directed CTL induction is possible by unlinked minigene DNA immunisation, but that CTL induction solely is not always sufficient to provide protection.
Article.ArticleTitle: Induction of cytotoxic T-cell responses by gene gun DNA vaccination with minigenes encoding influenza A virus HA and NP CTL-epitopes.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Virology, Statens Serum Institut, 5 Artillerivej, DK-2300, Copenhagen, Denmark. afo@ssi.dk.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Administration in vivo to prevent or reduce disease
FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 2 doses of 1 Î¼g plasmid DNA coated gold particles 6 weeks apart.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 2 weeks after final dose mice were challenged with a 100,000 TCID50 dose of source species.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Even when animals immunized with a minigene encoding the epitope develop strong CTL responses against both peptide pulsed and virus infected APCs, no enhanced survival is seen in animals challenged with a lethal dose of the source species.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 2 doses of 1 Î¼g plasmid DNA coated gold particles 6 weeks apart.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 2 weeks after final dose splenocytes were harvested, incubated 5 days with stimulator cells loaded with peptide and used for CTL activity assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Immunization with a minigene encoding the epitope without the natural flanking sequences enhances the CTL response, while only 1 in 5 mice gave positive responses when three 5' and four 3' flanking residues from WT NP sequence were included. When a minigene was constructed to harbor this epitope along with another epitope from the source species (as 'pearls on a string'), no CTL response was obtained with this epitope, but if both epitopes were co-administered and encoded by different plasmids, a strong CTL response was seen.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 10 days after infection, splenocytes were harvested, incubated 5 days with stimulator cells loaded with peptide and used for CTL activity assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: A strong CTL response was obtained by peptide stimulation of splenocytes from mice sub-lethally infected with the source species, when measured against peptide loaded APCs.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 2 doses of 1 Î¼g plasmid DNA coated gold particles 6 weeks apart.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 2 weeks after final dose splenocytes were harvested, incubated 5 days with stimulator cells loaded with peptide and used for CTL activity assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Immunization with a minigene encoding the epitope elicits a strong CTL response against source species infected APCs.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Administration in vivo to prevent or reduce disease
FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 2 doses of 1 Î¼g plasmid DNA coated gold particles 6 weeks apart.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 2 weeks after final dose mice were challenged with a 100,000 TCID50 dose of Influenza A (Puerto Rico 8/34).

AssayInformation.AssayComments: When mice are immunized with a minigene encoding the epitope and splenocytes are stimulated with either source strain peptide or Puerto Rico 8/34 peptide FEANGNLI, 1 out of 5 from each group develop CTL responses against the corresponding epitope, but no enhanced survival is seen in mice challenged with a lethal dose of the Puerto Rico strain.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 2 doses of 1 Î¼g plasmid DNA coated gold particles 6 weeks apart.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 2 weeks after final dose splenocytes were harvested, incubated 5 days with stimulator cells loaded with peptide and used for CTL activity assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Immunization with a minigene encoding the epitope elicits a strong CTL response against source species infected APCs.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 2 doses of 1 Î¼g plasmid DNA coated gold particles 6 weeks apart.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 2 weeks after final dose splenocytes were harvested, incubated 5 days with stimulator cells loaded with peptide and used for CTL activity assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Immunization with a minigene encoding the epitope with or without the natural flanking sequences produces weak CTL responses (1 positive out of 5 mice in each case), while 5 out of 5 mice gave positive responses when the epitope was encoded as a fusion fragment with HBsAg, implying that a different flanking region, providing immunological help, supports the processing and CTL response. When a minigene was constructed to harbor this epitope along with another epitope from the source species (as 'pearls on a string'), weak CTL response (1 out of 5 responder mice) was obtained, but if both epitopes were co-administered but encoded by different plasmids, a strong CTL response was seen.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 10 days after infection, splenocytes were harvested, incubated 5 days with stimulator cells loaded with peptide and used for CTL activity assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL responses against epitope were obtained by epitopic peptide stimulation of splenocytes from mice sub-lethally infected with Puerto Rico 8/34 strain, where the homolog epitope sequence is FEANGNLI.
